> > Why don't you like keeping your tests in the same package scope,
> > but (optionally) in a physically separate directory ?
>
> One reason that I don't like it too much is that I cannot see the
> application code and the test code side by side in my package browser - at
> least not in Eclipse. That's why I prefer to have both classes and test
> classes in the same source tree as long as the code is in a constantly
> changing state. I move the test classes out as soon as the code is in
> "almost stable" state. Of course, I'd prefer the browser to merge several
> source paths into a single view.

This is my first post here, hope I'm not breaking the rules.

I find keeping test code and src in separate source tree very neat.  I've
written a small script that can toggle easily between the test code and
source code for the editor that I use.  Because the source tree is like
src/foo/bar.java and the test source tree is like test/foo/bar.java.  When
I'm in src/foo/bar.java, I just substitute *src* to *test* to open
src/foo/bar.java, etc. I've never used Eclipse before, but it should be
fairly easy to implement this idea for any programmable editor or IDE.

Regards,

Yiu Wing
